editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A08922 of text S120123 in the English Short Title Catalog (STC 19200). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 21 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 12 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

publicationStmt.publisher: At the three Cranes in the Vinetree by Thomas Dawson, for Thomas Charde,

notesStmt.note: "A notable decree of the Lordes of the Parliament house of Paris, bearing the date the 26. of Iune, 1582. Pronounced against William Buhigue, containing a punishment for banquerouptes, namely the wearing of a greene cappe or hatte." is caption on A2r.
Running title reads: A greene cappe for a banqueroupt.
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

ns0:epHeader.ns0:title: A nevve order for banqueroupts.
ns0:epHeader.ns0:author: France. Parlement
ns0:epHeader.ns0:defectRangePerGrade: The rate of 5.64 defects per 10,000 words puts this text in the B category of texts with fewer than 10 defects per 10,000 words.
